scenarioDescription:
The HD 5319 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 5319 is a star with 1.27 times the mass of the Sun, and 4.06 times its radius. It is located 395.97 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3.1 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 5319 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 5319 system


HD 5319 b

HD 5319 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2007-12, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.57 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 5319 b is 494.808 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 5319 b is 13.500 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 5319 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 5319 c

HD 5319 c was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2015-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.93 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 5319 c is 334.854 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 5319 c is 13.800 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 5319 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 5319, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory.
name: HD 5319 - System With 2 Exoplanets
